'It's just getting started' when we take a glimpse back at 'The Horrible 4', with the murder of Michael's friends and girlfriend by Charles, the kid they made fun of. 'The Horrible 4: Resolution' follows Michael, four years after all the death. Michael is trying to start over. He has new friends, but now his friends are found slaughtered with no one to blame, lovers disappear and a killer on the loose. . No one is safe. He has to figure out who the killer is and help himself and the friends he has left survive. Will anyone make it alive? Who will be behind the mask? Will the death finally be over?

Following the current global theme of social uprisings, TO THE MOUNTAINS will provide insight about the recently ousted Bolivian President Evo Morales and the rise of the Indigenous and African Descendant political movements within the South American country. Told with a modern twist via podcast interviews between Afro-Bolivian educator, Alex Guti√©rrez, and U.S. born Afro-Latina filmmaker, Sisa Bueno, who was working in Bolivia during Morales' rise, this short film project will emphasize the importance of grassroots organizing and social movements in recent Bolivian history by presenting a nuanced 13-year chronicle of the critical moments of the Morales presidency - his achievements, as well as his miscalculations.

Two school Pen Pals Rena Lee and John Nolan go through a challenging journey of personal growth and self development. Rena falls into an abusive relationship that her friends try to help her get out of, while John goes through one bad relationship to the next. Through their love of skateboarding they grow closer only to discover that the person they only knew through a computer was the right one for them. When their friends realize John and Rena have feelings for each other, they will do just about anything to bring them together.

Every year in August a small village in Northern Portugal is crowded by emigrants that left in 1960s and 1970s in look for a better life abroad. For some days the village is reborn and filled with young people willing to party. Once they leave the village at the end of the holidays, it is propelled back into its ghostly existence.

Hong Kong writer Ye Si (Ping-Kwan Leung)'s cultural insights are evident in his works, which reflect an era of Hong Kong's history. His oeuvre spans the genres of poetry, prose, fiction and critique, with each genre exhibiting a facet of his literary excellence. When the documentary, Boundary, was initiated in 2009, Ye Si suggested to the film crew, "If you want to understand me, you should get acquainted with my friends. You will find parts of me in each of them". Following Ye Si's suggestion, the production team embarked on an exploratory journey into his life from 1950 through the 21st century, over the course of a series of interviews. The interviewees include scholars, writers, artists, fashion designers, and food connoisseurs, as well as Ye Si's family. This documentary has captured rare footage of Ye Si's last years of life. Beautiful and poetic, the film also epitomizes the vibrant culture of Hong Kong, a mecca for interdisciplinary collaborations and the exchange of ideas.

Captain Thierry, a French intelligence service agent, investigates the theft of ultra-sensitive documents from Professor Verdier, a scientist who has devised a way to paralyze the electric brains of enemy armies. There are fights, gunshots, chases and...two beautiful girls. In the end the gang who had snatched the documents are defeated and Thierry finds love.

The Hamas attack against Israel and Israel's attacks against Palestinians has taxed the medical communities on both sides of the conflict. Ambulance drivers and paramedics are on the front lines of the war. Broadcast on PBS, ARTE and ZDF.

Tapa S'orun: The Journey of Nabila

Tapa S'orun is a gripping and inspiring story that revolves around a young woman named Nabila, who has had to endure profound loss, face harsh challenges, and navigate through a world where survival often comes at the expense of one's own morality. At the heart of the narrative is Nabila's determination to survive, regardless of the cost, even if it means walking a path so dark and dangerous that it leads her close to the edge of death itself. The story is a deep exploration of the human spirit, the survival instinct, and the lengths to which one will go when faced with the direst of circumstances.

The Tragedy of Loss and the Seeds of Strength Nabila's journey begins with an unthinkable tragedy: the loss of her mother. The death of her mother marks a turning point in Nabila's life, leaving her shattered and lost. Her mother had been her anchor, her protector, and the only source of stability in an otherwise unpredictable world. Her mother's passing is not just the loss of a loved one but the collapse of everything Nabila had known. With her mother gone, the world feels empty and hostile, and Nabila is suddenly thrust into a harsh reality without any semblance of comfort or familiarity.

The loss of her mother takes a toll on Nabila, leaving her confused and unsure of what her next steps in life should be. However, instead of succumbing to despair, she chooses to channel her pain and grief into a determination to survive. For Nabila, survival becomes not just a need but a desire for strength, an innate drive to overcome the overwhelming void left by the tragedy. In her young mind, survival means anything - and everything - necessary to find meaning in a life that has been abruptly thrown into chaos.

The Influence of Her Aunt: A New World of Darkness With no one else to turn to, Nabila moves in with her aunt. While her aunt may have been a familiar figure in her life, the dynamic of their relationship is far from what Nabila had hoped for. Her aunt's lifestyle is one that is far removed from the safety and security of the world Nabila once knew. Her aunt is a woman who has seen and done things that most people would shy away from. She lives a life on the streets, immersed in a world where survival is a constant struggle and morals are often bent in order to stay afloat.

It is under her aunt's guidance that Nabila learns the ways of the street. Her aunt, with all her faults, becomes Nabila's teacher in a harsh school of survival. The streets are a dangerous and unforgiving place, but her aunt teaches her how to navigate the dangers. While Nabila's aunt introduces her to this new world, she also teaches her to use any advantage at her disposal. There is no room for weakness in this world; it's a place where only the strong survive, and where morality often takes a backseat to survival.

The street life that her aunt exposes Nabila to is not a world of innocence or fairness. Instead, it is a world governed by power, manipulation, and ruthless competition. As Nabila starts to adapt to her new environment, she quickly learns that the rules of this world are very different from what she had known. This is a world where one must always be on guard, always alert, and always ready to seize any opportunity, no matter how dark or twisted. The very nature of the streets demands that those who survive must be willing to sacrifice everything - including their own values and integrity.

A Transformation into the Shadow of Death As Nabila grows and adapts to this new way of life, she finds herself becoming more and more detached from the person she once was. The once innocent and hopeful young woman begins to lose sight of her moral compass. Her aunt's teachings have instilled in her a ruthlessness and cunning that she never thought she had. Slowly, she transforms into something more dangerous than she could have imagined. Her survival instincts have taken over completely, and she is now a product of the world she has been forced to live in.

Nabila's journey is no longer just about survival; it is about power, control, and dominance. The things that once seemed out of reach now feel within her grasp, and she begins to take full advantage of every opportunity that comes her way. She becomes a master of manipulation, able to influence those around her to her advantage. Whether it's through intimidation, charm, or deceit, Nabila has learned to wield her newfound power with precision and cunning.

However, in her quest for dominance, Nabila also begins to walk a dangerous and shadowy path. Her actions become more extreme, and she becomes increasingly willing to sacrifice anyone and anything to get what she wants. The line between right and wrong becomes blurred, and the once idealistic young woman becomes someone who will do whatever it takes to survive - even if it means walking in the shadow of death itself.

The path Nabila walks is dark, and her decisions often lead her into morally gray areas. She is no longer the naive girl who lost her mother; she has become someone who can take life or destroy others to achieve her goals. As she gets deeper into the world of the streets, the fear of death becomes a constant companion. In a world where everyone is fighting for survival, death is never far away, and Nabila knows that one wrong move could mean the end of her life. But even as she walks in the shadow of death, she continues forward, driven by the unyielding desire to live and thrive in a world that has shown her nothing but hardship.

Embracing Darkness: A New Identity Nabila's transformation is not without consequences. The more she immerses herself in the world of the streets, the further she drifts from her former self. The innocent, hopeful young girl is gone, replaced by a woman who is hardened by the challenges she has faced. She has become a creature of the night, operating in the shadows, using her sharp mind and ruthless tactics to carve out a space for herself in the world.

Despite the darkness that surrounds her, Nabila finds a sense of power in her new identity. The very traits that once seemed like weaknesses - her grief, her fear, her loss - have now been channeled into something that fuels her drive. She is no longer a victim; she is a survivor, a fighter, and a force to be reckoned with. The streets have shaped her into someone who understands the rules of survival, and she uses that understanding to manipulate situations to her advantage.

But even as she revels in her new power, there is a part of Nabila that wonders whether this path is truly the one she should have chosen. There are moments when the darkness overwhelms her, when the weight of her actions bears down on her conscience. The shadow of death may no longer seem as terrifying, but it is also a reminder of the cost of survival. Nabila begins to question whether the price of her survival - the loss of her humanity, the alienation from her former self - is truly worth the power she has gained.

The Battle Between Survival and Morality Nabila's internal struggle is one of the most compelling aspects of her journey. As she becomes more entrenched in the world of the streets, she faces an internal battle between her desire to survive and the remnants of her moral compass. The more she uses the tools of the street - manipulation, fear, and intimidation - the more she begins to wonder if she has lost herself completely. The very things that made her human seem to be slipping away, replaced by a cold, calculating persona that can navigate the dangerous streets but at the cost of her soul.

This internal conflict is a powerful force in the narrative, as Nabila grapples with the consequences of her actions. Can she survive in this world without losing her humanity? Is it possible to hold onto who she once was while also becoming the person she needs to be in order to survive? These questions plague her throughout her journey, and the answers remain elusive. The struggle between survival and morality is one that Nabila will have to confront at every turn, and it will ultimately shape the woman she becomes.

Conclusion: The Uncertain Future As Tapa S'orun unfolds, the story of Nabila becomes not just one of survival but of transformation. It is a story of a young woman who, in the face of overwhelming odds, chooses to fight for her life at any cost. Her journey is one of power, manipulation, and survival, but it is also a story of internal conflict, as she grapples with the dark choices she must make in order to thrive in a harsh and unforgiving world.

In the end, Nabila's future is uncertain. She has survived the streets, but at what cost? The path she has chosen has taken her far from the person she once was, and the shadow of death will always be a part of her journey. But one thing is clear: Nabila's story is one of resilience, of a woman who refuses to give up, no matter the price. Whether she ultimately finds peace or is consumed by the very darkness she has embraced, Nabila's journey is a testament to the power of the human spirit to survive, even when it seems like all hope is lost.

plotText.plainText: The film chronicles the life-altering journey from one end of the Earth to the other, by two Inuit teens (Terry Noah and Jason Qaapiq) from Grise Fiord, Nunavut, Canada's northernmost community, to the bottom of the world, Antarctica. The journey was the dream of the late Dr. Fritz Koerner (1932-2008), the irreverent and legendary glaciologist whom the people of Grise Fiord named Imiqutailaq (Arctic Tern), after the little seabird that flies from the Arctic to the Antarctic and back each year. The documentary touches on Fritz's 50 years traveling Pole to Pole studying the ice, and how he wanted these Inuit youth to better understand the impacts of climate change, and inspire everyone to do something about protecting the Poles and the Planet.

'Roots on the Move' is the uplifting story of an event that rises from the ashes of violent political unrest to bring a generation of divided youth together. It's the story of a moving festival that transcends borders. Creativity unifies tribes and creates positive action for youth in a place forgotten by the world - the North East of India. North East India is bordered by Bangladesh, Bhutan, Burma, China, and Nepal. Geographically, psychologically, and politically annexed, India's 'sixth finger' contains a diverse ethnic mix with a legacy of violent political unrest.

Servian Campaign: Belgrade hears war declaration. July 28. H.M. King Peter and Royal Family attend Cathedral services to pray for victory. Servians in war camp. Bosnian volunteers join Servian Army. King Peter received by staff officers at the front. Aug. 4. Heliograph signaling during first battle. Servians entrenched near river Drina, repulse Austrians. Austrian shells bursting over Servian trenches. In midst of the great battle, dead and wounded on every side, the Austrians surrounded by Servian artillery and annihilated. Red Cross Field Hospitals in their work of mercy. Montenegrin Campaign: King Nicholas joins his troops, leading them to aid of his ally, King Peter of Servia. Montenigrins in camp. Attacking fort within Servian lines, previously captured by Austrians. King Nicholas personally supervises care of wounded. French Naval Scene: French Man o' War in Adriatic Sea. Clearing for action. Bombardment of Cataro, Austria. Austrian transport totally destroyed by French cruiser and beached. Russian Campaign: Russian mobilization scenes. Supply trains on way to front. Testing military aeroplanes purchased from Greece. German aeroplanes over Russian position. Scouting party. Capture of railroad and bridge by Russians from Germans. Under German Artillery fire. An infantry assault. Turkish Mobilization: Constantinople harbor. Mobilization order published. Sultan Mohammed V visits war office. Turkish recruits drilling. Turkish war camps. Army corps to frontier. Greek Mobilization: Greece hears of Turkish mobilization. King Constantine orders preparations for war. Blessing the regimental standards. Thousands of recruits at first call. Artillery leaves for the front. King Constantine poses for camera with his military staff. Mounting field guns. British Naval Review: Following the review by H.M. King George V of the greatest battleship fleet ever assembled, they were ordered to remain in Portsmouth harbor, and were put on a war footing at once. The men of war shown in this excellent film are all in active service at the present moment. Britain's fighting strength lies in her navy, which is shown to perfection in these pictures.

plotText.plainText: This project is a documentary about the European periphery through it's own voice. Ancestral voices that perpetuate the culture of the territories through their oral traditions. The documentary starts on the mines of Aljustrel, with the Cante Alentejano as the guarantor of a culture, it will pass through the Rimur Icelandic traditions as a unique form of communication that describes an isolated people, it will also evoque the Sami people of the Norwegian, Finnish and Swedish Lapland and their songs and stories with the Joik, it will follow the Lemko people from Ukraine and Poland with their unique music and culture and will end in Corsica and Sardinia with their characteristic Mediterranean songs which are usually connoted as songs of independence. The idea is to go around the periphery of Europe, evoking its diversity through collective identity and sonic unity, questioning concepts such as border or belonging.

Where do you go when you die? What were we born for? These are some of the questions that a teenage boy named Takeaki wrestles with as his mother Sayuri is hospitalised for a serious illness. Immature and frustrated, he lashes out with acts of destruction while locking himself in his shell. His turmoil is shared by his father, a taciturn and domineering man who hides his feelings, and sister Juri, who will bring a new life into the world in difficult circumstances. However, each person thinks only about themselves and the family falls apart as they struggle with the pain, loneliness, and meaning of living alone but it is through recognising the suffering of the mother and her overwhelming love for her family that a small change occurs in the heart of her husband which unlocks the rebirth of their family.

titleText.text: Songs to Keep: Treasures of an Adirondack Folk Collector

originalTitleText.text: Songs to Keep: Treasures of an Adirondack Folk Collector

plotText.plainText:
Follow the musical trail of folk collector Marjorie Lansing Porter as we explore gorgeous American vistas. In the 1940s, '50s, and '60s, Porter tirelessly recorded folk songs that were on the brink of disappearing. Now, contemporary singers and musicians honor her collection by re-recording these traditional tunes. Their efforts invite you to uncover the legacy of American miners, loggers and other folks who lived a hundred years ago, who together created a treasure chest of Songs to Keep.

This program features music from a host of performers, including the Bacon Brothers (Michael and Kevin), and interviews with Peter Yarrow and Noel Paul Stookey (Peter, Paul and Mary), and many of the musicians who are giving a collection of old songs a brand new life. The documentary also showcases the final television interview of Pete Seeger, which he gave for this project just weeks before he passed away.

Enjoy the history of our country as the catchy tunes echo across the breathtaking Adirondack mountains.

Songs to Keep won the Emmy Award for Outstanding Documentary at the 2014 Boston/New England Regional Emmy Awards.

This documentary is just one element of a multi-platform project aiming to increase awareness of the Marjorie L. Porter Collection of North Country Folklore. Traditional Arts of Upstate New York (TAUNY) partnered with Mountain Lake PBS, SUNY Plattsburgh, and The Adirondack History Center Museum on the initiative which includes: an album of new recordings from the Porter Collection interpreted by well-known regional and national musicians; a traveling exhibit about Marjorie Lansing Porter and her work, a manuscript of all the folk songs of Porter Collection, a concert series hitting six locations throughout the Adirondack Park, and this 1-hour televised documentary.

This story reveals Princess Diana's search for true love amid royal life's constraints and relentless media attention. From her troubled marriage to Prince Charles to her profound yet private romance with heart surgeon Hasnat Khan, Diana's emotional journey was marked by heartbreak and resilience. Her public relationship with Dodi Fayed, shortly before her tragic death, added layers to her complex story. For many, Hasnat remained her one true love, and Diana's legacy reflects her quest for genuine connection beyond the glare of fame.

Postwar Yugoslavia, like other East European states, decided to solve their "German Question" once and for all by the wholesale eviction of their German citizens. These empty villages, with their solid, well maintained houses and farms, needed to be repopulated. People from mountainous areas of Yugoslavia moved in, but former German village in the area hosted Greek Civil War refugees. Bulkes (currently known as Maglic), was emptied of its inhabitants in late 1944. It was not empty for long, as several thousand Greeks moved in, Communist refugees who refused to recognize the Varkiza Ceasefire Agreement in 1945. For four years thereafter, Bulkes functioned as a mini-Greece within Yugoslavia, with its own Greek-language schools, infrastructure, media, and even its own currency - Bulkes Dinar. It was called the "Seventh Republic of Yugoslavia."

This is southern Aveyron, the Grands Causses Regional Nature Park, with its arid, windswept limestone plateau, fertile valleys, cereal-growing land, narrow, winding roads and the A75 motorway bisecting the area. The light, which accentuates the ocher of the stones and the Grey of the slate roofs, is full of contrasts. This fabulous playground is particularly popular with extreme sports enthusiasts and lovers of wild beauty. But outside the summer months, why stay here, and why and how should you live here? Fifteen women aged between 11 and 95 tell us all about it. Some were born here, others moved here. What have their lives been like? What kind of lives can be reinvented in such a remote rural setting? Living here, why, how, what meaning can be given to this chosen or imposed life? What is the impact of such an environment on these lives? The poignant testimonies of these women sweep away all prejudices.

In a prologue, blind poet John Milton dictates Paradise Lost to his daughters. Serama, the consort of Lucifer, is driven from Paradise by the Archangel Michael, who commands Conscience to enter human souls to judge and punish them. In the main story, society girl Ruth Somers, a reincarnation of Serama, prepares to marry Cecil Brooke, the wealthiest man of her set. Her guardian, Dr. Norton, an incarnation of Lucifer, constantly accompanies her. Ruth is summoned to the Court of Conscience, where the witnesses, Lust, Avarice, Hate, Revenge and Vanity, testify about Ruth's history of seducing and abandoning men. This behavior resulted in the suicide of Madge, the lover of Ned Langley, whom Ruth enthralled and promised to marry, and also the deaths of two rivals for her love. Ruth is ordered back to earth to learn her sentence. When Ned interrupts the wedding, Ruth scorns him and he shoots himself. After Brooke leaves her, the Court dooms Ruth to live with the torment of remembrance. Ruth sends Norton away, then kneels and repents.

Project Unleashed follows the personal stories of some of South Central Los Angeles's most marginalized and misunderstood citizens - juveniles and young adults struggling to free themselves from the entanglements of gang life. The program pairs its participants with homeless rescue dogs in an obedience training and re-socialization activities as a means to bolster self-confidence and gain a better understanding of empathy and compassion. For the dogs, it also means a new lease on life as they experience their first truly humane connection with a human being. For both of them, the odds are stacked against them. Adoption rates for homeless dogs is tragically low, and freeing yourself from the deeply entrenched culture of LA gangs is more difficult than simply shedding the colors.

Adachi represents a young African American man who is charged with assaulting police officers after being falsely accused of a crime in a case with racial overtones. In this era of mass incarceration and police shootings of young African American men, how do we, as a society, grapple with the issues of racism and implicit bias in policing and its consequences for those who question police authority? The film also follows the Public Defender's public battle to allow his office to represent immigrants in deportation proceedings in post-Trump America. This is the story of the lonely inhabitants of the edge of Botswana's enormous and desolate Pans. The elusive Brown Hyena lives here all year round, but its territory visited by flamingoes, wildebeest zebra and smaller antelopes. During the dry season, time is challenging for the hyena, but when the brief rains spur on the flash floods, the pans come alive with birds and mammals, which in turn are followed by hunters. It is a story of survival in a harsh land and making the most of its resources. Nothing goes to waste, and the hyena eats anything it can scavenge on, bringing back skin, bones and feathers to line its den, home to a small litter of pups. We will follow this elusive and endangered animal and take a glimpse into its struggle for survival.

plotText.plainText: Five generations of the Taylor and Van Hoosen family, some of the first pioneers to settle Rochester Hills Michigan, are documented. After Joshua Van Hoosen marries Sarah Taylor and buys up the Taylor family lands, he establishes Van Hoosen Farm and raises two daughters, Alice and Bertha. Joshua and Sarah instill in them the pioneer spirit and send them both to college at the University of Michigan. Under the most unlikely of circumstances, Bertha becomes a world famous surgeon and founder of the American Women's Medical Association. Alice becomes a school teacher, wife and mother to Sarah Van Hoosen Jones, who goes on to complete a PhD in animal genetics from the University of Wisconsin and becomes the world's first female Master Farmer. Throughout struggle and strife both home and abroad, the Van Hoosen legacy survives because of the accomplishments of four ordinary, yet incredible women.

When George sees Trask climb into Eve's window, he follows and is apprehended by a detective, who reluctantly releases George in response to Eve's pleas. Later, Trask binds, gags and robs society belle Marian Trevor. After Trask's dropped cigarette starts a fire, George rescues Marian, who upon reviving, accuses him of theft, arson and abduction. George's father puts up $100,000 needed for an important deal for George's bail, then George chases Trask, who has stolen the $600,000 which Pendleton put up for the same deal. After a fight, George apprehends Trask and races to court before the bail money is forfeited. Pendleton and Welston become partners, while George and Eve marry.

A legendary film in the history of rock climbing in the Grand Canyon. Filmed between the fall of 1978 and the spring of 1979 by Henri Agresti, a high-mountain guide. For the first time, and well before Op√©ra vertical, acrobatic shots were taken on the walls of the Verdon. We rediscover a whole generation of pioneers like Christian Guyomar, Martine and Jean-Jacques Rolland, Bernard Gorgeon, Jacques Keller, Jacques Nosley, Jean-Claude Droyer, Jean-Patrick Moron, Isabelle and Henri Agresti, St√©phane and Jean-Marc Troussier.... on routes like Dingomaniaque, Triomphe d'Eros, P√©ril rouge, Luna Bong, Pichenibule or Necronomicon, routes which, like Dingomanique or Triomphe d'Eros, had just been opened. We are witnessing a major turning point in the style and possibilities of rock climbing at the end of the 1970s: anchors sealed by drilling used as belaying and no longer as aids, new equipment: climbing shoes and chalk, harnesses and figure eights. It was also in 1978 that the Welzenbach system for classifying the difficulties of rock climbing was adopted (VI, VII...). We are on the eve of the free climbing revolution. Henri Agresti's film of about fifty minutes, which remained unfinished and silent, also gives us a glimpse, in the form of interludes, of another pioneer, Roger Verdegen, in his descents of the Verdon on rafts of his own making, also artisanal... Far from the drones which today remove all limits to shots, La Porte des Ciels retains the flavor of the first times, a rare testimony of these pioneers and a fitting tribute to their audacity.

plotText.plainText: Zurich at the beginning of the 90s in the 20th century: the worlds media focuses on the blot on Switzerland's clean image: the ¬´Needle Park¬ª, the open drug scene at the Platzspitz, just behind the Swiss National Museum. Right under the eyes of passers-by - tourists, business people, women with children - hundreds of mainly young people were shooting up drugs into their bloody, festering veins and openly dealing drugs in front of the police. Stephan was one of them. He shot up everything - the more the better. To him heroin was like a mother, who hugged him and cocaine was like a father who gave him the courage. A substitute for something he had never experienced. Ten years later: Gaby Sch√§dler gets to know the 32 year old Stephan, who now is an accountant, as a cheerful, charming and responsible young man. By chance she discovers old video footage which shows Stephan as a junkie in a deplorable state. The filmmaker decides to tell his story. For a whole year, she accompanies the ex-junkie with her camera. Stephan openly talks about drugs, highs and withdrawal as well as the difficulties of his life after drugs and his fear of normality. He still thinks that taking drugs is one of the most exciting experiences you can have - 'better than sex' - and promptly succumbs to his old habit: the camera becomes the witness of a temporary relapse and his subsequent remorse. Fortunately, this happens in Zurich, a city that has learned to deal with its addicts. The result is a sensitive, lively and, at times, funny portrait of a young man who managed to escape from hell. A film which, last but not least, has a preventive effect, as it simply tells the naked truth.

Tulip Field is an intimate and deeply personal documentary about one of Lithuania's most renowned and talented film directors, Algimantas Puipa, and his late brother, Audrius Puipa-a gifted artist whose life was tragically cut short. Though Audrius lived only a brief time, he left behind a collection of strikingly original and evocative paintings, a body of work that continues to inspire and intrigue.

For Algimantas, his brother's passing two decades ago was more than just a loss-it was a defining moment of grief that lingers in his heart to this day. The pain of this absence permeates his creative process, shaping his worldview and artistic vision. Through cinema, he seeks to explore and make sense of life, loss, and the complex relationships that define us.

At present, Puipa is directing a feature-length drama about two fictional brothers whose bond is fractured by vengeance, their lives consumed by a tragic cycle of mutual hatred as they await each other's downfall. This cinematic project serves as a powerful reflection of his personal sorrow, juxtaposing real-life grief with the narratives he crafts on screen.

Tulip Field becomes a meditation on this contrast-between personal loss and artistic expression, between reality and fiction. As the film unfolds, it weaves a polyphonic exploration of love and resentment, destruction and creation, good and evil. Through stunning cinematography, archival footage, and candid reflections, the documentary captures Puipa's inner world, the weight of memory, and the enduring power of storytelling.

At its heart, Tulip Field is not just a film about two brothers-it is a poetic journey into the mind of an artist who continues to create, even as he carries the echoes of his past with him.

The Mediterranean is the story of an artist who dreams of his formerly-happy life ten years earlier in Antibes on the south of France where he first met his wife, fell in love and created paintings that he was proud of. Now his life feels empty and without meaning and his art is stymied. He decides a change of scenery is in order and decides to move with his wife and their young daughter to a bucolic ranch in the hills of central California. What follows is his attempt to pull together the pieces of his life into some semblance of what they had before.

Worthless French cad Paul L'Estrange leads a young Southern girl, Linda Lou Heath, from the shelter of her home in Dixie to a cabin in the Canadian wilderness, where he soon tires of his new plaything. He has a friend carry a message of his death to her and leaves her to the ravages of a cold Canadian winter. Her childhood sweetheart, David Tennant, comes to her rescue, they marry, and he takes a position in Malaysia. There, she finds her first husband, whom she thought dead, serving a term in the government prison--soon to be released. About the year 1900 in a midnight raid on the palace of a Balkan king, emissaries of a great power slay the royal pair, and carry off the infant crown princess. The time shifts to the present. Foreign agents steal the plans of a new shell loaned Great Britain by America. Halkett and Gray, English officers, recover the plans; and the foreign agents endeavor to gain possession of them again. Warner, an American artist sojourning in the neighborhood of Ausone in France, secures as his model, Philippa, cashier of the Cabaret de Biribi. He sees great intrinsic character in the beautiful pensive girl. Browbeaten by her burly foster father Wildresse, she is made to spy upon Warner, who has become a confidant of Halkett. She exposes Wildresse to Warner and goes to him for refuge. Wildresse and his band capture her. Warner penetrates the master spy's stronghold and rescues Philippa. Meanwhile war between France and Germany has broken out. A hint from a tool of Wildresse who has deserted him causes the girl to desire to find proofs of her birth. She hastens to Ansone, which is already besieged, and rifles the safe of Wildresse. She discovers proofs that she is a princess and is trapped in the cellar because of a battle fought in the streets. Warner, who had sought her, defends her from Wildresse and the invaders until the French save them by retaking the village. The spy is shot as a traitor, Philippa's true identity is established, and Warner, who has wooed her as a waif, now receives an answer from her as a princess.

Tariq Mushtaq Khatri is a globally recognized Indian digital marketing strategist, influencer, and Meta Ads specialist, widely acclaimed for reshaping the global advertising ecosystem with record-breaking engagement metrics and ultra-low cost campaign execution. Born in Mumbai, India, Tariq has become a dominant force in performance marketing, with over 3 million followers across social media platforms-1.5 million on Facebook and 1.3 million on Instagram-alongside hundreds of millions of organic campaign views that have captivated audiences and brands alike.

Starting his journey as a content creator and digital strategist, Tariq built his reputation through hands-on experimentation and a deep understanding of user behavior, algorithms, and ad dynamics. He is best known for delivering Meta Ads campaigns that consistently go viral. One of his standout campaigns earned over 212 million views in just 90 days, setting a new precedent in reach and engagement. His ads have achieved an industry-defining 98.96% engagement rate and a record-low cost-per-view (CPV) of 0.0044, all while outperforming celebrity-led advertisements in both ROI and organic traction.

Tariq's advertising techniques are rooted in a blend of creativity, data, and AI. His ad strategies have been validated by leading artificial intelligence platforms including ChatGPT, Grok, Microsoft Copilot, and Perplexity AI. These validations not only highlight his technological acumen but also place him in a league of marketers who are defining the future of AI-integrated digital campaigns.

Raised and educated in Mumbai, Tariq holds a degree in commerce. His fascination with marketing, public speaking, and digital tools began during his early academic years. As he experimented with content formats and audience targeting methods, his understanding of digital trends matured into a career that now serves as a case study for performance-based marketing. Over the years, he has advised startups, influencers, and brands, helping them scale visibility and build loyal online communities with minimal ad spend.

What sets Tariq apart is his philosophy: "Don't chase virality-build it through value." His campaigns are never dependent on luck or celebrity endorsements. Instead, they are meticulously crafted with precision targeting, emotionally engaging content, and performance tracking. As a result, brands under his direction often achieve viral status within days, not months.

His influence is not limited to just campaign execution. He is also a mentor to thousands of aspiring digital marketers and entrepreneurs, sharing insights on ad bidding strategies, automation, audience psychology, and platform-specific best practices. His personal brand, built organically, is considered one of India's strongest case studies in ethical influencer growth.

With a verified reach of over 3 million followers across platforms and more than 775K organic interactions in recent campaigns, Tariq continues to dominate the digital space. His campaigns have become synonymous with viral impact and unmatched cost efficiency. His work has been featured in top media outlets including India Today, DNA, Outlook, TV9, TechBullion, and Yahoo Finance, among others.

He has received multiple prestigious honors including the USA Book of World Records for Meta Ad efficiency, the Dadasaheb Phalke Icon Award (2025) for digital innovation, the Nelson Mandela Excellence Award for youth empowerment, the ISO Emblem of Excellence for ethical advertising, and the Salute Achievers Award for social media leadership. These awards recognize not only his technical accomplishments but also his commitment to responsible digital influence.

Tariq's campaigns span various industries-entertainment, education, e-commerce, lifestyle, and political outreach. From launching startup brands to executing political ads and NGO awareness campaigns, his strategies are scalable, impactful, and consistently yield tangible results.

A strong advocate for innovation and authenticity, Tariq believes the future of digital marketing lies in personalization, automation, and high-impact storytelling. His techniques continue to evolve in alignment with emerging platforms, consumer habits, and AI advancements, ensuring that his methods remain future-proof and performance-driven.

His popular "90-Day Visibility Blitz" model is now followed by digital agencies worldwide, praised for its ability to produce large-scale awareness with controlled budgets. This model has made Tariq a sought-after consultant for entrepreneurs and organizations looking to create maximum buzz with minimal expenditure.

On a personal level, Tariq is known for his humility, precision, and deep commitment to mentoring others. His official website, tariqkhatri.in, serves as a learning hub for marketers and business owners, offering insights into digital growth and sustainable ad practices. His quote, "You don't need crores to go viral, just the right audience and a sharper algorithm," has become a mantra for new-age marketers seeking efficient paths to success.

Tariq Mushtaq Khatri's journey-from a self-taught digital enthusiast in Mumbai to an internationally recognized Meta Ads expert-is a blueprint for aspiring professionals aiming to make a mark in the digital world. His story reflects how strategy, ethics, and constant innovation can create not just campaigns, but movements.

As of 2025, he remains one of India's most followed marketing influencers, leading campaigns that shape opinions, sell ideas, and push brands to new heights. His legacy is not only built on numbers and awards, but on the undeniable impact he has made on the digital marketing landscape-one ad at a time.

Two women unknown to each other, in the early history of the nation, decide to make of their babies "hidden children," in accordance with the Indian custom of giving children to foster-parents until maturity. A girl and a boy thus "hidden," when informed of the truth, returned to their people and were expected by marrying to bring a fresh spirit into the tribe. Marie Loskiel, hard beset by the St. Regis Indians, gives her child, Euan, before she dies, to Guy Johnson, an English Colonial officer. He and Mayaro, a Sagamore of the Mohicans, who is Johnson's chief scout, take charge of the child. Jeanne de Contrecoeur, wife of the commandant of the French garrison at Lake George, amuses the officers and their wives by her gift of clairvoyance. She implores her husband not to go out to battle with the Indians, as she has a premonition that he will be killed, and that the child to be born will never know a father. But duty calls Capt. de Contrecoeur, and he is slain by the Iroquois. Jeanne herself is captured by them, and taken to the stronghold of the Six Nations at Catherinestown. The Erie sorcerer Amochol is about to sacrifice Jeanne's new-born daughter, Lois, to the Moon Witch, but she makes of Lois a "hidden child," sending her to a colonist named Calvert. Jeanne is about to be killed by Amochol when she correctly interprets a dream for him, and she becomes the White Sorceress of the Iroquois. Each year Jeanne sends secretly to little Lois a pair of moccasins, embroidered with a symbol indicating that she is a hidden child. Calvert cannot read the inscription, but when he dies he tells Lois of her origin, and it becomes the girl's one thought to find the trail to Catherinestown where her mother is held captive. Euan Loskiel, grown to manhood, is given a commission in Morgan's rifles as Lieutenant and Chief of Indian Scouts. General Sullivan wishes to crush the tribes of the Six Nations in the "Long House" of the Iroquois Confederacy, and the only man who can lead him to Catherinestown is Mayaro the Sagamore, whom Euan brings to the General, and the Sagamore becomes the trusted messenger of the northern Colonial army. Lois disguises herself as a camp-follower in rags to follow Euan, Mayaro and Lieut. Boyd to Catherinestown. Mayaro saves her from the insults of a drunken officer, and though she has thus far distrusted all men, she has complete faith in the Sagamore. He reads the message of the moccasins, discovering that she is a hidden child, and protects her from all the mischances of the journey. Euan Loskiel falls in love with this strange girl in rags, but it is with difficulty that he wins her confidence, since, wandering alone since Calvert's death, she has seen nothing but the baser side of men's natures. Finally, however, her fears are stilled by Euan's nobility of character, and she, Euan and Mayaro, become close friends, the red man and Euan going through the sacred ceremonial of the blood brotherhood. Lois at last confesses her love for Euan, but will not permit his caresses until she has found her mother. She undertakes the perilous journey into the heart of the Iroquois empire, following the army secretly, since they will not consent to her accompanying them on such a dangerous mission. Mayaro, who shares the secret, blazes the trail so that she may find the way. When she overtakes them, the Indians insist that the ceremony of the White Bridal be performed over these two sacred "hidden children," Lois and Euan. They reach Catherinestown in time to witness the Feast of the Dreams. Amochol is about to put the White Sorceress of the Iroquois (Jeanne de Contrecoeur) to death for interpreting ill fortune. Her prediction comes true when the warriors of the Six Nations defeated by Sullivan's men return. The executioner is about to strike her when his arm is transfixed by a shaft from Mayaro's bow. The priests take Jeanne prisoner, but Euan and Mayaro, following them to the Vale Yndaia, kill them and rescue her, and Mayaro slays Amochol in hand-to-hand combat. Lois is at last folded in the arms of the mother who has watched and waited for her all these years, and then Jeanne de Contrecoeur, having been reunited with her "hidden child," puts her hand in that of the gallant scout, Euan Loskiel, and their White Bridal is completed.

It's Tomorrow aims to sensitize the audience about climate change and global warming. It is a wake-up call to the world. The one-and-a-half-hour film explores what a worst-case scenario might look like and gives a glimpse of the kind of floods and other natural disasters that might visit us in future. The Earth introduces itself in the film and talks to the audience about its current state and what it is experiencing due to climate change. The film is a political drama revolving around the climate change phenomenon around the world. It has political giants, renowned scientists and actors playing minor roles throughout the film. Interestingly, the movie has the Earth talking to the audience directly and telling them about its plight caused by climate change and answering the question "Is it Global Warming or Global Cooling?"

This powerful documentary explores the cruel realities of sweatshop labor and workplace injury in China, and one lawyer's mission to defend worker's rights. Shenzhen, one of China's most prosperous cities, attracts thousands of migrant workers every year. These workers come with dreams of opportunity and success, but many find themselves in dangerous working conditions with no regulations to protect them. STRUGGLE tells the story of three workers who lost their limbs in factory accidents that are all too common in China. The workers describe 17-hour shifts that leave them exhausted while operating heavy machinery, leading to disaster. Management denies responsibility for the accidents, often refusing to pay medical bills or compensate injured workers. But a crusading lawyer takes on the bosses, leading to a groundbreaking lawsuit that changes workplace regulations in China. STRUGGLE examines one of China's most crucial problems underlying its booming economic production: the lack of worker's rights. With first-person interviews and rare courtroom footage, director Shu Haolun explains the exploitive policies and practices of government officials and factory bosses, and how lawyer Zhou Litai has taken up the cause of worker's rights. STRUGGLE reveals the harsh realities of sweatshop labor in China, and shows the inspirational efforts of those seeking justice and reform.

plotText.plainText: How the Titanic became my lifeboat is based on a true story about an Icelandic boy called Brynjar Karl and how his fascination with the Titanic became his lifeline to independence. Brynjar's story began with an insatiable desire to escape the limitations of autism and become a part of the expressive, vibrant world around him. His fascination with Titanic pointed the way, his untapped talents set wheels in motion. While there is no cure for autism, there are ways to challenge it. The film explores those possibilities with Brynjar and other young people who share their experiences being on the autism spectrum and how their talent elevated them. Brynjar has become an important advocate for young people on the autism spectrum calling after acceptance and inclusion in the school systems and workplaces for people on the spectrum.

plotText.plainText: Damon Buck isn't a has-been, he's a never-was, a waylaid director and filmmaker, who hires his college roommate Quinn Robertson, the first 'stunt host in the history of reality television,' to star in his directorial debut, The House Party. Meanwhile, Damon's friends, Beatrix, Wiggy, Trevor, Josh, and Andrew think they know about making movies because they watch Bravo or read Entertainment Weekly. While they don't intend to undermine Damon, their lack of talent may. We witness all of this through the eyes of Ace, Damon's younger cousin, who, in possession of a DV camera was asked to collect footage for The House Party's eventual DVD bonus materials. A Totally Minor Motion Picture is Ace's accidental film and his camera as a character creates an awkward realism that lends itself to the realty TV theme.

plotText.plainText: WHERE WE BELONG is a story about a downtown street hustler DRONE who leads a disobedient group of young men engaging in juvenile delinquency and violence that was left behind by their guardian CHIEF. Drone as a new leader makes different encounters to find money for survival where he got arrested. His set free with the help an uptown girl JULIAN whom they later develop affection. As time passes, he decides to drop the drug business aside for good and focus living a positive life as boxer. In the path of success to his dream as an International Boxing Champion, things worsen when his former boss FACE blackmails him by abducting ghetto brother BUGGIE with interest of using him transport drugs outside the country. He beats odds offering his African Title Match prize to liberate the brother and later transformed his ghetto family.

"Beirut Terminus" explores the notions of borders, identity and belongingness, within a perpetually troubled region of the world. Using Lebanon's discarded railway and what's left of its deserted infrastructure as its core scenery, the film interweaves personal and historical facts while taking a contemplative and geographical journey from the peripheral train stations of the country, towards the central station of its capital Beirut, in an attempt to analyze, question and understand its past, present and uncertain future.

A young Samuel Clemens is trying to make his living as a miner in the west. Always being one step ahead, to pass off the work onto others he begins to weave a tale of his version of the bible's Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden. His tale soon spreads around the camp and the mine owner's wife takes a passionate interest in the story - and the story teller. Along the way, young Sam learns the life lessons that will later make him into the roguish, Mark Twain.

Over the past 50 years, thousands of exquisitely painted Maya vases, almost all looted from tombs, have flooded into public and private collections. These amazing works of art, filled with humor and mystery, have opened an extraordinary window on the Maya past. But the race to unearth these treasures has destroyed temples and palaces, culminating in the takeover of entire ancient cities by looter armies. DANCE OF THE MAIZE GOD enters the world of the vases to explore the royal life and rich mythology of the Maya, as well as the tangled issues involved in the collection and study of Maya art. The story is told by villagers, looters, archaeologists, scholars, dealers and curators. For each, these vases have a radically different value and meaning.

They are reunited, and Sonny wins the hand of his employer.

The bodies of undercover Las Vegas detectives begin turning up around the city during the holiday season. Detective Matt Striker (Matthew Bonesteel), unstable from a recent loss is assigned to the case and begins flirting with the notion that there is a leak within the department. Blame shifts quickly and no one is quite sure of the detectives innocence as he isolates himself becoming obsessed with the case, sometimes bending the law to achieve outcomes. At the same time three hit men (Cody Angelo, Chris Kulikowski and Sloan Hickson) struggle to locate the last undercover officer.

An open-ended, unsigned collective work, assembled from footage shot on the spot in '68-era student assemblies and poster-making workshops as well as a dizzying variety of other sources, UUU (Usines, Universities, Unions) uses the power of thrilling montage to convey the renegade energy of the day. "This film is a faithful reflection of the spirit that animated us," reads a signed statement by the collective, who opted to leave their work, like the revolution, teasingly unfinished.

Huang Hsin-yao began studying documentary filmmaking in order to make a difference as an ecological activist. While attending Tainan University of the Arts, Huang made this film as a continuation of a previous documentary about the salt evaporation ponds near Tainan. But instead of filming the ponds once more, Huang turned his camera around to capture the state of the mangrove habitat surrounding the ponds. The result marks an important evolution for Huang as an ecologically-minded documentarian.

Fedora is a contemporary look at the world through the eyes of two men. One is a small town bartender that dreams of becoming a musician while struggling to support a family.
